importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ricky Hatton was found unresponsive at his home on this date, leading to the inquest into his death.
A memorial service for Ricky Hatton was held on this date, attended by prominent figures in boxing and pop culture.
The inquest into Hatton’s death was adjourned to this date, indicating ongoing investigation and public interest.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Ricky Hatton retired in 2012 after a career that spanned from 2007 to 2012, during which he had a record of 45 wins and three losses, including a notable undefeated streak until his loss to Mayweather in 2007.
The period from late 2025 to early 2026 saw public reaction and inquest proceedings following his death, reflecting ongoing societal attention to athlete mental health and safety.

keyTakeAways: Ricky Hatton, a former world boxing champion, died by suspected hanging at his home in Manchester on September 14, 2025.
The inquest, led by senior coroner Alison Mutch, concluded that the provisional cause of death was hanging.
Hatton had last been seen well by family on September 12, but missed an event and was found unresponsive on the morning of September 14.
Hatton was a former world champion in light-welterweight and welterweight classes, known as 'The Hitman', and had a record of 45 wins and three losses.
He had a history of public struggles with alcohol, drugs, and depression, which contributed to public concern about mental health in athletes.
Hatton was scheduled to return to the ring in December 2025 for a comeback fight against Eisa Al Dah in Dubai.
His death prompted widespread tributes from top figures in boxing, including Amir Khan and Tyson Fury, and a memorial service was held in Manchester.
The memorial included notable attendees such as Liam Gallagher and Wayne Rooney, highlighting Hatton’s cultural influence beyond sports.
Hatton’s body was placed in a blue casket with 'Blue Moon' inscribed, referencing the song he used as his ring-walk song and a nod to his fandom of Manchester City.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Ricky Hatton, the former world boxing champion known as 'The Hitman', died by suspected hanging at his home in Manchester on September 14, 2025. The inquest, led by senior coroner Alison Mutch, determined that the cause of death was hanging. Hatton, who had a career marked by victories over top fighters such as Floyd Mayweather Jr., Manny Pacquiao, and Kostya Tszyu, had last been seen well by family on September 12 but was found unresponsive the next day. Despite public acknowledgment of his struggles with mental health, including depression and substance use, he was set to return to boxing for a comeback fight against Eisa Al Dah in Dubai in December 2025. His death triggered an outpouring of tributes from fellow champions and public figures, including Tyson Fury, Amir Khan, Liam Gallagher, and Wayne Rooney. A memorial service was held in Manchester on October 10, attended by many prominent figures, and his body was laid to rest in a blue casket inscribed with 'Blue Moon', a tribute to his love for Manchester City football and his personal ring-walk song.
title: Former world boxing champion Ricky Hatton died by suspected hanging, inquest hears
